moves.1. g3: I usually play unusual openings in ladder games, for the same reason I construct themed minis of offbeat openings. It does get boring to play your 50th Ruy Lopez in 3 months.
moves.1... e5 2. Bg2: Finish what you start! Must complete the fianchetto.
moves.3... Nf6 4. Nf3: Now Black can't drive this Knight with P-K5.
moves.4... Bd6 5. Nc3: No need to castle yet, since the game hasn't gotten tactical at once.
moves.5... a5 6. a4: Putting a stop to any immediate Q-side ambitions Black may have.
moves.8... Bxc3 9. Bxc3: No reason to double the Pawns.
moves.9... Nbd7 10. e4: Seizing my share of the center.
moves.11... Nc5 12. b3: The best way to defend a Pawn is with another Pawn, in most cases.
moves.15... bxa4 16. bxa4: Have to complete this exchange first.
moves.16... Ncd7 17. f4: Now I look to open some lines.
moves.17... exf4 18. Qxf4: I figure Black will eventually castle on the K side, so I may as well start an attack there.
moves.19... Nxf6 20. Rab1: Can't completely ignore the Q side, so I seize an open file. All my other pieces will focus on the K side.
moves.20... O-O 21. g4: Looking to sweep forward with the Pawns.
moves.21... dxe4 22. Bxe4: Now the B is activated. Black had a chance to trade it off but did not, an error that would come back to haunt him.
moves.22... Qd7 23. Bf5: Moving out of the Knight's fire with tempo.
moves.23... Qa7+ 24. Kh1: Black isn't going to go down meekly. He intends a counterattack.
moves.26... Rfe8 27. Be4: Cutting the link on the file.
moves.27... Nc3 28. Rbe1: Counterattacking the Q in an attempt to regain the initiative.
moves.28... Qd4 29. Qg2: Threatening to fork the Rooks with BxP.
moves.29... Rec8 30. Bxc6: I win a Pawn in any case.
moves.30... Ra6 31. Qf3: Focusing on Black's vulnerable K position.
moves.33... Kh7 34. Be8: Now I just have to get my Pawn to cover the potential attack square at Black's KN3.
moves.37... Rxc2 38. Bg6+: If Black plays ...RxB, he loses the Exchange. If he moves his King...
